bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 23, 1875

div1.p: Reed writes Emilie Lawrence that he is lonely without her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, July 23, 1875
div1.p:
I prom
-ised to write you a short
letter to-night, & you shall
not be disappointed- I
am of opinion that you
will experience some
difficulty in decipher-
ing it, owing to the rough-
ness of the Chesapeake
& the tossing of the boat.
I have already broken
my pencil once & as
it is very short, I can
not afford to lose
much of it, or I'll have
none left with which to
finish my letter- I have
just come in from the
forward deck, where I
have been watching “our
Gem of the Sky” (your Ex-
pression, you'll remember)
& thinking of the precious
girl I've, to-day, left.
I watched it till a dark
cloud obstructed my view
& then came in to give my
thoughts expression on
paper- Ah! my darling,,
how lonely I feel to-
night without you!. What
would I not give to see
you for a few moments-
I wonder if my sweet
little Emilie is thinking
of me to-night & would
she like to have me by
her side- I'll think as
much anyway & rest
happy in the thought- I
can see you now, my
darling, as you stood
by the window, to-day,
When I bade you goodby
bye- I see that sweet face
which is more lovely, in
my eyesight, than all
others on earth! Onelook
look at it & I was com-
pelled to quickly say
“goodbye,” for my heart
was in my throat-
Oh! my dear little sweet-
heart, how many times
must this sad parting
be repeated? I trust
not many, since I
could not bear them.
But since there must
be a few such trying
moments, let us bear
them with fortitude &
alleviate the pang by
keeping each other
fresh in our memory-
Never were you so dear
to me as to-night- Oh!
if I could tell you of my
unbounded love! Lan-
guage could but feebly
express my feelings-
Thank God! You are
mine for all time!
Good-night, my darling, &
may a company of bright
angels guard your couch
to-night- I go to dream
of you-
